Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Automated and community-driven synthesis of the tree of life
Award.AbstractNarration:
The tree of life links all biodiversity through a shared evolutionary history. This project will produce the first online, comprehensive first-draft tree of all 1.8 million named species, accessible to both the public and scientific communities. Assembly of the tree will incorporate previously published results, with strong collaborations between computational and empirical biologists to develop, test and improve methods of data synthesis. This initial tree of life will not be static; instead, we will develop tools for scientists to update and revise the tree as new data come in. Early release of the tree and tools will motivate data sharing and facilitate ongoing synthesis of knowledge.

Biological research of all kinds, including studies of ecological health, environmental change, and human disease, increasingly depends on knowing how species are related to each other. Yet there is no single resource that unites knowledge of the tree of life. Instead, only small parts of the tree are individually available, generally as printed figures in journal articles. This project will provide the global community of scientists who study the tree of life with a means to share and combine their results, and will enable large-scale studies of Earth's biodiversity. It will also create a resource where students, educators and citizens can go to explore and learn about life's evolutionary history.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported participation by the Hibbett laboratory of Clark University in a collaborative endeavor called the "Open Tree of Life". The goal of the project was to collect phylogenetic (evolutionary) trees in electronic form and combine them using new algorithms to yield a comprehensive synthetic tree of life. The synthetic tree also includes lists of taxonomic names, including those of organisms that have yet to be included in phylogenetic analyses. Thus, the synthetic tree represents, to the extent possible, the total knowledge of biodiversity and evolutionary relationships for all life. This knowledge is tremendously valuable for understanding the diversity and history of life, and it enables scientists to predict the distribution of organismal traits and understand their biogeographic relationships. This was a complex undertaking, involving a team of researchers with interests in evolutionary biology, bioinformatics, and biodiversity of diverse groups. The products of this work can be viewed here: http://www.opentreeoflife.org/. There was also a significant outreach component, which led to construction of an educational website: http://etreeoflife.com/.

The Hibbett laboratory was specifically responsible for collecting and uploading data on fungi, which represent a large and poorly understood branch of the tree of life. Fungi are exceedingly diverse; current estimates suggest that there may be as many as five million species of fungi, or more, but only about 125,000 have been formally described. The synthetic tree will provide a guide to the known diversity of fungi (and other organisms) which will help mycologists in their efforts to document the remaining undescribed species. Fungi also have huge economic and ecological impacts as decomposers, pathogens (including agents of human diseases) and beneficial symbiotic organisms, such as mycorrhizal fungi. The synthetic tree will provide clues to the distribution of organismal traits that could have practical applications, such as production of antibiotics and enzymes with industrial value.

In total, 1138 fungal phylogenetic trees were uploaded, and they are now available for use by the community of researchers in fungal and evolutionary biology and bioinformatics. The Hibbett lab also coordinated with experts on biodiversity informatics and fungal databases to assemble the taxonomic information (i.e., lists of names of described organisms) that was also incorporated into the synthetic tree. Other project partners provided data on plants, animals, and microbes.

This award supported two postdoctoral fellows and four undergraduates, who assisted with research. In total, 19 peer-reviewed articles and two book chapters were published, and numerous presentations were given at national and international conferences. Finally, the methods and products of this research were incorporated into an undergraduate course on phylogenetics at Clark University (Molecular Systematics and Evolution, BIOL 254) that was taught by the PI and Postdoctoral Fellow, Romina Gazis.
